captions.text: So, today's theme is the future.

I'm going to talk about a growing epidemic 
and what we might do to stop it.
But first I'm going to start in the past.

About 15 years ago,
I was an eager, young, graduate student
and I spent a lot of time teaching.

I really liked my students,
I got to know them very well,

and the more I listened
to my female students,

the more I picked up
on something troubling.
These bright, talented, young women

were spending alarming amounts of time
thinking about, talking about,

trying to modify
their physical appearance.
They wanted so much to feel beautiful.

Now, our perceptions of beauty
are complicated.
They have deep evolutionary roots.

From a scientific perspective,
beauty is not just desirable,
but also rare.

So, what's struck me was not that
these women wanted to feel beautiful,

or that they didn't all feel beautiful
all the time.

Instead, what's struck me
was that their quest for beauty

seemed, at least at times,
to overrule, to overwhelm
every other goal or interest they had.

These were young women
just embarking on their adult lives
and they were worried.

They worried that they were too fat,
they worried that their skin wasn't clear,

they worried that they were already,
at the tender age of 20, getting wrinkles,

they worried that they didn't look like a
"Sports Illustrated" swimsuit model
or a Victoria's Secret angel.

They worried that they had cellulite,
they worried that they weren't a size 00,
and I was worried about them.
So, I went to my grad school adviser

and I said, "I got an idea,
this is what I'm going to study,
right, this is going to be my thing,

and in particular I'm going to consider
how images like this
might be affecting women."
And she said, "Mm, na, don't bother."

"You don't need to look at that,"
she said,

"because really, smart women,
they know better.

They know better than to be affected by
things like media images."

And I said, "Well,
that's an empirical question."

So, based on the research
I've conducted since then,
I have to say she was kind of right.
In some ways, women do know better.

This is an advertisement
I use in one of my studies,

and I'm going to show you some responses
from research participants.

So, women know that the images
of women they see in the media
are often unusually thin,
possibly even eating disordered.

They know the women
they see in these images

aren't representative of
the general population of women,

they understand that
they're statistical outliers.
And on top of that,

women are very aware
that in the real world
nobody, nobody actually looks like this.

So, that's the good news,
women do know better,

they know about eating disorders,
they know about Photoshop, that's great.

Here's the bad news, it doesn't help,
it doesn't seem to matter.

Knowing better isn't enough,
The same woman who said this, for example,

"This body type is unrealistically skinny,
and her ribs are showing,"

and you're kind of like: yeah, right on.
She followed it up with,
"I'm not as skinny.

Should I go to drastic
weight-loss programs and tan,

risking my health?
I feel like I want to be like that,
I wish I was a model.

Maybe after seeing this picture,
I won't want to eat."

That's not what you want here as a
researcher, using this picture,
I have to tell you, but we moved on.

This is not a failure
of information processing,
it's not a failure of intelligence,

and it is definitely not
a failure to know better.

This is beauty sickness, and that's what
I'm going to talk about today.
Now, do only women get beauty sickness?
No, it can afflict men too,

but women are much more likely
to hate their bodies.

Women spend more money on beauty,
they spend more time on beauty,

there at 10x greater risk
for anorexia and bulimia.

Women are more likely to get
commentary about their physical appearance

from friends, from romantic partners,
from sometimes complete strangers.

There were a little over 1.5 million
cosmetic surgeries in the US in 2012.
Almost 90% of those went to women.
So, today I am going to talk about women.

What are these symptoms
of beauty sickness?

I see beauty sickness when women
who are full-time college students,
not professional models,

tell me they know exactly what to do
when someone pulls a camera out.

The women where I teach have shorthand
for it -- I'm going to demonstrate it.

It's side, out, down,
tilt, skinny arms.

And you get, apparently,
extra points for this.
I don't know if you got that.

Here's one of my students
who's kind enough

to let me put this picture
in the slideshow.

Here are two others who are 
demonstrating the pose as a joke
at their senior formal.
That's how ubiquitous it is.

Now, what's wrong with wanting
to pose in a flattering way

when your picture is taken?
Nothing...

...But, it's worth asking,
how did we get to a point

where so much of
women's time and energy

is being taken up by concerns
that used to belong

only to professional models
and actresses?

And more importantly,
what happens to women

when their energy is so intensely
focused on their own appearance?

So, physical beauty comprises
a number of characteristics,

but for women there is one that swamps
all others in terms of importance.
Do you know what it is?
Yeah, it's weight, right, it's body size.

There's a statistic that's
often bandied about in conversations
about women's obsession with body size,

but actually comes from a survey in
"Esquire" magazine in 1994.

But it gets a lot of attention,
because, apparently,

54% of women said they would rather
be hit by a truck than be fat.
I'd like to first knowledge that "Esquire"

is not where we turn
for careful scientific research!

But... I'm fascinated by reactions
to this statistic.

I brought it up in class once.
I said, "Class,

54% of women would rather be
hit by a truck than be fat."
And I expected to see outrage.

But instead of seeing horror on
the looks of my female students' faces,
I heard a series of questions.

I heard, "How big is the truck?"
(Laughter) "What kind of truck?"

"How fast is it going?"
(Laughter)

and, "Just how much, exactly,
would it hurt?" (Laughter)

And it kind of makes sense,
I think probably getting hit by a truck...
...hurts.

But there's something else
that hurts too,

and that's living in a culture
where you are bombarded

with these three messages,
over and over, and over gain:

Message 1:
Beautiful is the most important,

most powerful thing
a girl or woman can be.

Message 2:
This is what beauty looks like, and,

Message 3, which is sometimes implicit,
it's sometimes just an inference:
You don't look like this.

It shouldn't surprise anyone
that, in laboratory studies,

when we expose women
to images like this,
even for just a few minutes,

it increases depression and shame,
it reduces self-esteem,

it lowers body satisfaction,
this is beauty sickness.

Our sense of what's real,
what's possible when it comes to beauty,

is warped by our overexposure
to these images.

Instead of seeing them for what they are,
which is extraordinarily rare,

we start to see this
as typical or average.

So, you can look around the world
and you can see that men and women

are getting fatter,
but the body ideal for women

is getting thinner and thinner, so that
the distance between what a woman is

and what she longs to be gets
bigger and bigger.

It's not a small gap,
it's a gaping chasm.

If you look in that chasm,
you're going to see beauty sickness.

Now, when evolutionary psychologists
look at images like this,

they make the argument
that this kind of beauty is like sugar.

In our modern times, we're getting
too much of it, in too high-up doses.

Our brains don't quite know
what to do with this.

It's not good for us.
It gives us the message,

that this is typical,
even though it's not.

So, it warps our sense of what's real,
it's making us sick.

What other signs do I see in
our culture of beauty sickness?
If we look at popular online news sources,

well -- we'll pick on
"The Huffington Post" today --

they cover things like crime and
politics and world news and education,

and, then, as you probably know,
they also cover really important things,

like what famous women look like,
what they're wearing,

whether they've gained weight,
how they've lost weight.

These are all from the same day
on "The Huffington Post",

two of them were on the front page,
when I took the screenshot.
Beauty sickness is what happens

when women spend so much time worrying,
not about their education,

their career goals, their family
or their relationships,

not about the state of the economy,
the state of the environment,

the state of the world,
because they're too busy

worrying about
their weight-loss goals,

their skin care regimen,
the state of their arms,

the state of their abs,
the state of their thighs.
How did we get to this place?

According to a set of ideas
called objectification theory,
here's how it works.

Women live in a world
where they're taught

that their primary form of currency
is their appearance.
And you can't escape it.

You walk down the street and
people comment on your appearance,

advertisers tell you
how to be more beautiful,

television programs,
even news programs,

ridicule women who fail to meet
traditional beauty standards.

Your appearance is so chronically
observed by other people

that, over time, you internalize
that perspective,
so you become an observer of yourself.

Instead of moving around,
looking out at the world,

you spend all of that time imagining
how you look to the world.

Is my hair okay?
Is my forehead shiny?

Am I standing up straight?
Am I sucking in my stomach?

Am I smiling the right kind of smile?
Do these jeans make me look fat?

Do I have muffin top?
Do I have skinny arm?
Do I look okay?
Right? You've internalize this notion

that your body is always, always
on display for other people,

always up for evaluation,
so you better keep an eye on it too.

Now, psychologists have long told us
that we have finite cognitive resources.

So, just as, despite
my students protestations,

I hold that you cannot be on Facebook
and text and pay attention in class

at the same time.
(Laughter)

You also cannot chronically monitor
your body's appearance
and be engaged with the world.

So that's the worst outcome
of beauty sickness.

When you are beauty sick,
you cannot engage with the world,

because between you
and the world is a mirror.

And it's a mirror that travels
with you everywhere,
you can't seem to put it down.

It's beauty sickness
that makes women self-objectify,

that makes our young girls
want to grow up to be sexy things.

I spoke on a panel last fall
about media images,

and I got a question from
a young woman in the audience.
And she said, "Isn't this power?

Right? If women can
get things, valuable things
from this culture by being beautiful,

shouldn't we embrace that as a form of
power that's uniquely available to women?"

And I get it, I really do,
I get what she's saying.

But what kind of power,
at least what kind of real power,

is so ephemeral,
what kind of power expires

when you're thirty, or maybe forty,
if you are lucky or a celebrity?

What kind of power
is inversely correlated

with the attainment of wisdom
and life experience?

I want to reiterate here that
there is nothing wrong with beauty.
Our brains are so sensitive to beauty.

We know it when we see it,
we process it in milliseconds.

This desire to be beautiful,
the desire to be desired,

it is not something you can
completely shut off in the brain.

Wanting to be beautiful
is not the problem;

the problem is when it's all
our young girls and women want to be.

I would like young girls
and women to be like this,

I'd like them to be
so much more than hot.

So, how can we turn the tide
against beauty sickness?
Here are just a few ideas.
So, first: invest less in beauty.
Instead invest in things that last,

into things you don't have to fight
to keep in middle and older age.

If television shows like this
leave you thinking
more about your appearace instead of less,
stop watching them.

If there are magazines that
leave you obsessed with a body ideal

that most women can never
realistically achieve,
stop reading them.

Try not to think of your body
as a collection of parts
for other people to look at.

Think of your body
as unified, as whole,
as your tool for exploring the world.

Stop worrying maybe about
the size of your thighs,

and think about the strength
of your thighs,
because those legs, after all,

are the legs that walk you
around in the world.

And stop talking about your upper arms
as though they are "diseased".

Those are the arms that reach out and
bring the things you love close to you.
As this anti-anorexia ad says,

don't let people make you into a sketch;
you can be more than this or this.

Because your body is not for looking at,
it's for doing things.
Another thing you might consider is,

just as some people like to limit
their children's screen time these days,
maybe limit your mirror time.

And since today's talk
is about the future,

here's a direct way
you can impact the future
with respect to beauty sickness.

You can stop telling little girls
they're pretty.

So every time --
it sounds counterintuitive, right?
-- don't tell them they're ugly!
(Laughter)
Don't do that either!

But every time you feel compelled
to comment on a little girl's appearance,

consider complimenting one of
her other many lovely qualities instead.

Do you need help?
Here are some ideas.

Consider noticing when she is smart
or hard-working or generous

or persistent or kind or brave,
and, when you do that,

you undermine the system
that teaches girls

their best bet for social status
is the pursuit of beauty.

Try to raise daughters
who see their appearance

as a minor sidenote to their character
and their hard work.
You can change this conversation.

We are never going to live in a world
where beauty doesn't matter.
Our brains weren't made that way.

But we can live in a world
where beauty matters less,

and these types of characteristics
matter more.

And, in fact, small changes
in the way we think,

and the way we talk, and the way
we interact with each other,

could pave the way for
a truly more beautiful future.
Thank you.
(Applause)

title: An epidemic of beauty sickness | Renee Engeln | TEDxUConn 2013

comments.text:
Well there´s a way of complimenting girls without saying typical things 
about their bodies. "You look good today" can´t do any bad in my opinion, 
because sometimes someone looks beautiful because she's woken up with 
energy or there's light in their eyes or they're smiling all the time or 
they simply look healthy, if you know what I mean. What is insulting is the 
way some men compliment women, which has nothing to do with what I have 
said, and they really think it is cool or even romantic. As a woman, I feel 
myself seen, watched even, as a piece of meat or a painting you stop to 
look at. Well, not even a painting, because art is suppossed to transmit 
you something but women are only suppossed to turn men on. That´s why most 
of your female students are so worried about their apperience, because they 
want to look good FOR BOYS, which is degrading and disgusting. And that is 
also the reason why most of the girls my age look similar, everybody tries 
to fit in that image of "what boys prefer". I fucking hate that.
Really good speech by the way, I´m so happy I found it.﻿
comments.author: Susi Dominguez

comments.text:
This TED sounds like telling women to change their skirts so they don't get 
assaulted. "Less mirror time" and less Huff Post reading won't change 
anything important. How about a discussion about the actual "worst outcome 
of beauty sickness"---sexual dysfunction, broken homes, wrecked finances, 
etc. Or research into where/how these casualties from Dr Engeln's "sugar" 
("poison") of modern culture originate with the men, married and single, 
who are chronically dissatisfied with their partners ---because they also 
have mirrors and read Huff Post and use the internet.﻿
comments.author: Cora Judd

comments.text:
Not sure about it being an epidemic, more like an Holocaust. Same goes for 
depression.﻿

comments.text: You're a very smart woman, Renee! :)﻿

comments.text:

comments.text: FANTASTIC!!!! More please. Feminist man here.﻿
comments.author: Mark Martin

comments.text:
As a overweight girl I can admit without disparaging myself that some women 
indeed DO look like the woman pictured in the water. Are they rare? 
Absolutely, but I wouldn't call crying "Anorexic! Eat a sandwich!" At the 
image "knowing better" or having a particularly mature understanding of 
what bodies look like.﻿
comments.author: Lin Gin

comments.text: Great talk. Front to back. Amazing.﻿
comments.author: TOLFINTRY

comments.text:
When I was young and quite attractive, thin, I had the worst experiences 
with guys. When I was 53 and over menopause, and had stopped caring about 
staying young and just was friends with myself, I met someone a little 
younger who said "the body isn't everything" who I had (and still have, 8 
yrs later) the most fulfilling relationship with ever. So girls -- find 
your bliss. Take care of yrself, sure, work out, eat well, love your work 
and stay calm, don't need a man to be happy...he'll find you. And if he 
doesn't, you'll still be happy loving yrself.﻿
comments.author: maryamakiling

comments.text: +maryamakiling Thank you, this is what I needed to hear.
comments.author: little lights

comments.text:
All the time while I was looking at her say "Beauty doesn't matter that 
much", guess what I was thinking??!!﻿
comments.author: Yasser Hussain

comments.text:
I like the beginning of this talk, but when it gets to suggestions, I feel 
like it's patronizing and limiting. I think it's delusional to say to stop 
teaching little girls that beauty is a primary access point to power 
without addressing the broader social structures that make that TRUE right 
now. Because it's true right now! The factors that lead to this beauty 
sickness create a world where beauty is prioritized not just by oneself -- 
then all these recommendations would certainly be enough -- but by others 
evaluating you. And unfortunately this is directly linked to other aspects 
of sexism including workplace inequalities and even gendered violence. I 
know a talk has to have a scope and perhaps this one just ends with one's 
pursuit of personal peace, but I just feel the need for a society-wide 
change is so integral to this problem that you really CANNOT stop with, 
"Put down the magazine, duh!"﻿
comments.author: Julie Ruble

comments.text:
+Julie Ruble I think you're rigth and I really agree that we should look at 
the oppresive institutions that make beauty a currency. But we can still be 
optimistic, and take over those institutions. We got this :)
comments.author: Rocío Campaña

comments.text:
And I guess you can say, "Well if everyone makes the personal change, that 
will create a societal change," but I actually feel like that's impossible 
without acknowledging the roles sexism and capitalism play in the problem 
(as opposed to just personally skewed priorities).
comments.author: Julie Ruble

comments.text: I hope to see the world as you said...you are so inspiring﻿

comments.text:

bruising and broken bones from a car wreck," but that's not really it. ﻿

comments.author: Ena Changes-Zin

comments.text:
Well let's be honest here. Who is happy being fat and ugly? The average 
woman is overweight not because that's normal, but because we overeat and 
don't exercise. Those healthy bodies are achievable and realistic, but only 
with some effort. If all you do is sit around and eat calories like crazy, 
why would you feel bad and criticize others who make the effort to exercise 
and eat right, if it was your fault on the first place the reason of the 
way you look? ﻿
comments.author: Bseriesxlp

comments.text: Great talk, thanks!﻿
comments.author: judy Osborne

comments.text:
An amazing way to start changing our attitudes. My mom used to buy me diet 
pills when I was a little girl and at 17, I finally developed anorexia from 
a long roller coaster of losing and gaining back weight. I'm always been 
shy, so as a little girl I spend a lot of time reading, drawing and 
studying. Anyone can suffer from an eating disorder.

There's a whole online sub culture that revolves around thinspiration. Just 
go to tumblr and you'll see what this woman is talking about. Girls are 
beauty sick. Woman is over sexualized by media and even by ourselves. In 
order to be sexy or hot you have to be either voluptuous or thin. And I'm 
not talking about looking hot to other people, but to be happy with 
ourselves.

For example, just look at women's fashion trends nowadays: denim booty 
shorts, see through chiffon shirts, bandeus (aka BRAS x.x ), skirts and 
dresses that barely cover your back, cropped shirts that show up your 
bra...and the list goes on.

A woman CAN choose to be sexy, but maybe we have a wrong concept about it 
because is clearly not helping women and children. Little kids thinking 
about being fat or ugly...I mean let them be children for God's sake.

I kind of being doing what you said and I'm better now. I'm back to a 
normal weight but it's hard not feeling like shit sometimes. I think maybe 
is all about learning how to control your thoughts , but some ideas never 
fade away. You just gotta distinguish between reality and idealization. 

Thank you so much for your wise words﻿

comments.author: MsCordially

comments.text:
+MsCordially I don't think the main point was that supermodel beauty is 
unattainable, rather that in the evolutionary past, what with its lack of 
magazines and films, actually seeing someone of such beauty would have been 
a relatively less common and more awesome event -- and which certainly 
would not have left the impression that perfection was the expectation. The 
point being made was that supermodel-standard physical beauty is not 
necessary for one to be found attractive and that trying to attain it at 
the expense of time better spent on other aspects of life is probably 
foolish.

comments.author: MsCordially

comments.text:
+MsCordially This is such a problematic comment, though, because you're 
missing the point entirely - their physical "beauty" (as determined by 
societal standards) should not characterize them as perfect and should not 
be the most important thing about them/that which gives them the most 
significant value. And to limit beauty to this physical "perfection" 
implies that these people are beautiful and others are less so, and in turn 
have less value.

She may be your personal ideal of perfection, but the inherent problem is 
that deeming Taylor "perfect" based sheerly on her physical appearance 
undermines the value of her talent, intelligence, and character, and 
continues to stifle the importance of those qualities in others. The 
problem here is that very idea that women "will look toward and admire or 
want to compete with" these so-called perfect individuals as a result of 
their perceived beauty, aspiring above all to attain that level of 
"perfection", and resultantly limiting their own energy/capacity to 
cultivate other aspects of their character.

comments.author: TimeTraveler

comments.text:
I can't believe there are reserachers on topics as this.   What she says is 
fairly obvious (and I don't even understand women well).   About the only 
interesting thing she said is don't compliment small girls on how pretty 
they are.

The source of these issues is free market (and associated capitalism), and 
indeed even democracy!    In a free democratic world, we're allowed to 
pursue our passions, and such passions have created unprecedented growth in 
world economies, through the free market,capitalistic system.

But free market works also by inflamming the passions.   That is, the most 
base desires tend to be the ones most easily for sellers to sell to.   
 Hence, the women's desire for beauty is an easy target to commercialize, 
via advertising and media saturation for beauty.

As long as advertising (a critical component of free markets) and desire 
for beauty exist, the correct free market answer is to saturate the medias 
with the optimal return point on inflamming this beauty desire--so as to 
sell to base desires.   Free markets does this moreso than other economic 
and political systems.

So, what's the answer, if we wish to retain the free market system?   
(Otherwise, we run  into free speech problems).

1. Outlaw photo and video enhancements of women's beauty characteristics.   
That is, show people as they are.
2. Outlaw cosmetic surgery.

I believe it will be difficult to outlaw natural beauty photos (e.g. Sophia 
Lorenz I believe never had cosmetic surgery).   But, the amount of 
inflammation of passions for overabundant amount of artifical beauty can be 
significantly reduced by the above.

Her solutions are unworkable.   1. Not look at magazines....  How can 
someone not do this when one's passions are so inflammed?   2. Not 
compliment little girls.... Good idea, but I still don't see how a single 
set of parents not complimenting will stop the rest of the village from not 
complimenting thus.

Outlawing certain  forms of exacerbting the current problem (photo touchups 
and cosmetic surgery) are better solutions.

To better understand this, there's an analogous example with men.   
 Pornography 50+ years ago was heavily regulated and frequently outlawed.   
 However, due to free speech and free markets, now pornography is simply 
over-saturated.    This is unhealthy for men (and ensuing women).   It is 
simplistic to tell men not to look at magazines or videos or to not to 
appreciate women's beauty when teaching them as little boys.   The correct 
answer is to also strongly regulate pornography as well.

Free speech is great, but excessive inflammation of passions, particularly 
by free market forces, is a serious downside of democracy, free markets, 
and capitalism.﻿

comments.text:
Yet another complex issue that is over simplified. I do think and agree 
with her that there is way to much focus on looking like the models, 
however; at the same time we cannot allow obesity to be acceptable. 
Americans on average, which she is American btw, are way more overweight 
than anyone in the world. A large shirt in Europe is a medium here in the 
US. We must take into account eating habits for both genders and say ladies 
and gentlemen this is not right. Secondly, this has to do with genes, some 
have them and some don't get over it. If you are a Social Darwinist you see 
it as natural selection is taking place and if you are a tree huger you see 
it as something very bad. And lastly, I think the whole rebellion from this 
movement is sparked by the new pro-feminine movement here in America. Which 
is not bad, but basically anything the far right of the movement sees as 
feminine they are going the opposite direction. That being said, I'm all 
for freedom of choice, but I think we all can agree advertising and media 
can be used in both ways to manipulate how we see each other. We must be 
careful of how we use that because we can start a whole other problem in 
the process. At the end of the day, it is who wins the fight and not how we 
feel. Life is tough, and we all must live with ourselves. The image we 
should all go for is take care of our bodies, food habits, and standards of 
education and behavior. Don't use a movement to crutch on like the 
stereotypes of ADD and ADHD kids. They are just as smart if not smarter 
than "Regular" kids. Same goes with this movement, just because they tell 
you are beautiful does not mean you are realistically. Male or female just 
take care of yourself and the rest will happen. Indifference is what makes 
us all unique. All it is is a mindset. ﻿

comments.author: Jean Kilbourne

comments.text:
She perfectly sums up an issue that has so worked itself into the fabric of 
life that it often feels impossible to quantify or explain. In 15 minutes, 
she presents the issue, how it harms us, the choice we have to change, 
practice tips for how to make changes, and a potential outcome that is too 
enticing to ignore. I applaud her for her research, her insight, her 
compassion, and her courage, and I am grateful to be able to view and share 
this video with others who need to remember that we have a CHOICE about the 
quality of life we live. There may be biology driving us, there may be 
culture coming at us, but the beauty of living our very personal life is we 
can choose (albeit it is often not an easy choice that requires much 
practice and mental redirection!!) our focus and our impact....and 
ultimately, our legacy.﻿
comments.author: Shannon Cutts

comments.text:
i have dated a few 20 year old girls as a 30 year old man and i can attest 
to what this lady is saying.  The obsession for self image was such a turn 
off for me that i had to get out of those relationships.   These younger 
girls are way out of touch with reality because of the over obsession of 
self image.   It is funny because every single one of the photos i can 
remember of those girls had exactly the pose she showed in the ted talk 
except they added the duck lip thing to it.   I appreciate the beauty of a 
woman and the efforts they put into it but when its all about being seen as 
beautiful it really does take away from just about everything else a person 
would desire in a relationship.   what dude wants to date girl that has to 
look in mirror for 2 hours before going out to dinner or something.   Its 
like yo lady i am your man and i am cool with you, why are you trying to be 
so hot all the time for everyone else to see?  Life is a balancing act of 
health, wealth, and love.    to much of any takes away from being whole as 
a person.    I still date younger women but it does seem a majority are 
obsessed with image and have no substance past that.   I have met a few 
girls that are well rounded and beautiful but they are like unicorns and 
are usually married or in a relationship.   I think self image changes as 
you mature.... i too was obsessed with what people thought about me until i 
was about 26 years old.   One day i just said F it and just stopped fearing 
peoples thoughts of me all together.  I wish i had that power growing up 
and looking back all i can assume is that i have matured past my self image 
obsession.      ﻿

comments.text:
+Brooke Johnson You cannot speak for all skinny people Brooke. They are not 
all you or like you. There is a wide variety of reasons why people are 
underweight and not all "underweight" people are sick. Some may be. There 
are conditions like food allergies and sensitivities, parasites, etc that 
can contribute. Not always. Some skinny women gain weight in their 40's 
when their hormones change. I'm old so I've been able to track my skinny 
school friends. I also work with people with eating disorders. Body shaming 
is huge for both skinny and fat and I'm speaking from my experience working 
with such people. I'm a nutritionist and do coaching to change underlying 
unconscious patterns and remove traumas. Don't be judging others. You don't 
know if they are healthy or not.

but I'm not giving up or getting down by that, and certainly I am not going 
arround looking for someone to blame for it. Instead all that I work to 
improve myself, by sport, intellectual challenge, and I know there is value 
to this. You kiddies should man up and do the same.
